044
045/**
046 * Parses and formats units of measurement as SI symbols, URI in OGC namespace or other symbols.
047 * This class combines in a single class the API from {@link java.text} and the API from {@link javax.measure.format}.
048 * In addition to the symbols of the <cite>Système international</cite> (SI), this class is also capable to handle
049 * some symbols found in <cite>Well Known Text</cite> (WKT) definitions or in XML files.
050 *
051 * <h2>Multi-threading</h2>
052 * {@code UnitFormat} is generally not thread-safe. If units need to be parsed or formatted in different threads,
053 * each thread should have its own {@code UnitFormat} instance.
054 *
055 * @author  Martin Desruisseaux (Geomatys)
056 * @version 1.0
057 *
058 * @see Units#valueOf(String)
059 *
060 * @since 1.0
061 */
062public class UnitFormat extends Format implements javax.measure.format.UnitFormat {
063    /**
064     * For cross-version compatibility.
065     */
066    private static final long serialVersionUID = -3064428584419360693L;
067
068    /**
069     * The unit name for degrees (not necessarily angular), to be handled in a special way.
070     * Must contain only ASCII lower case letters ([a … z]).
071     */
072    private static final String DEGREES = "degrees";
073
074    /**
075     * The unit name for dimensionless unit.
076     */
077    private static final String UNITY = "unity";
078
079    /**
080     * The default instance used by {@link Units#valueOf(String)} for parsing units of measurement.
081     * While {@code UnitFormat} is generally not thread-safe, this particular instance is safe if
082     * we never invoke any setter method and we do not format with {@link Style#NAME}.
083     */
084    static final UnitFormat INSTANCE = new UnitFormat();
085
086    /**
087     * The locale specified at construction time or modified by {@link #setLocale(Locale)}.
088     *
089     * @see #getLocale()
090     */
091    private Locale locale;
092
093    /**
094     * Whether this {@code UnitFormat} should format long names like "metre" or use unit symbols.
095     *
096     * @see #getStyle()
097     */
098    private Style style;
099
100    /**
101     * Identify whether unit formatting uses ASCII symbols, Unicode symbols or full localized names.
102     * For example the {@link Units#CUBIC_METRE} units can be formatted in the following ways:
103     *
104     * <ul>
105     *   <li>As a symbol using Unicode characters: <b>m³</b></li>
106     *   <li>As a symbol restricted to the ASCII characters set: <b>m3</b></li>
107     *   <li>As a long name:<ul>
108     *     <li>in English: <cite>cubic metre</cite></li>
109     *     <li>in French: <cite>mètre cube</cite></li>
110     *   </ul></li>
111     * </ul>
112     *
113     * @author  Martin Desruisseaux (Geomatys)
114     * @version 1.0
115     * @since   1.0
116     */
117    public enum Style {
118        /**
119         * Format unit symbols using Unicode characters. Units formatted in this style use superscript digits
120         * for exponents (as in “m³”), the dot operator (“⋅”) for multiplications, specialized characters when
121         * they exist (e.g. U+212A “K” for Kelvin sign), <i>etc.</i>
122         *
123         * <p>This is the default style of {@link UnitFormat}.</p>
124         *
125         * @see Unit#getSymbol()
126         */
127        SYMBOL(AbstractUnit.MULTIPLY, AbstractUnit.DIVIDE),
128
129        /**
130         * Format unit symbols using a syntax close to the Unified Code for Units of Measure (UCUM) one.
131         * The character set is restricted to ASCII. The multiplication operator is the period (“.”).
132         *
133         * <h4>Modification to UCUM syntax rules</h4>
134         * UCUM does not allow floating point numbers in unit terms, so the use of period as an operator
135         * should not be ambiguous. However Seshat relaxes this restriction in order to support the
136         * scale factors commonly found in angular units (e.g. π/180). The meaning of a period in a string
137         * is resolved with two Seshat-specific rules:
138         *
139         * <ul>
140         *   <li>Unit symbols shall not begin or end with a decimal digit or a superscript.</li>
141         *   <li>A period between two decimal digits is interpreted as a decimal separator.</li>
142         * </ul>
143         */
144        UCUM('.', '/') {
145            /** Replace non-ASCII characters on a "best effort" basis. */
146            @Override Appendable appendSymbol(final Appendable toAppendTo, final String value) throws IOException {
147                if (value.startsWith("°")) {
148                    final int length = value.length();
149                    if (length == 2) {
150                        switch (value.charAt(1)) {
151                            case 'C': return toAppendTo.append("Cel");
152                            case 'K': // U+212A (Kelvin symbol)
153                            case 'K': return toAppendTo.append('K');
154                        }
155                    }
156                    return toAppendTo.append("deg").append(value, 1, length);
157                }
158                final CharSequence cs = CharSequences.toASCII(value);
159                final int length = cs.length();
160                for (int i=0; i<length; i++) {
161                    toAppendTo.append((char) Characters.toNormalScript(cs.charAt(i)));
162                }
163                return toAppendTo;
164            }
165
166            /** Formats the power for a unit symbol. */
167            @Override void appendPower(final Appendable toAppendTo, final int power) throws IOException {
168                toAppendTo.append(String.valueOf(power));
169            }
170
171            /** Actually illegal for UCUM, but at least ensure that it contains only ASCII characters. */
172            @Override void appendPower(final Appendable toAppendTo, final Fraction power) throws IOException {
173                toAppendTo.append(EXPONENT).append(OPEN).append(String.valueOf(power.numerator))
174                           .append('/').append(String.valueOf(power.denominator)).append(CLOSE);
175            }
176        },
177
178        /**
179         * Format unit symbols as localized long names if known, or Unicode symbols otherwise.
180         *
181         * @see Unit#getName()
182         */
183        NAME(AbstractUnit.MULTIPLY, AbstractUnit.DIVIDE);
184
185        /**
186         * Other symbols not in the {@link Style} enumeration because common to all.
187         */
188        static final char EXPONENT_OR_MULTIPLY = '*', EXPONENT = '^', OPEN = '(', CLOSE = ')';
189
190        /**
191         * Symbols to use for unit multiplications or divisions.
192         */
193        final char multiply, divide;
194
195        /**
196         * Creates a new style using the given symbols.
197         */
198        private Style(final char multiply, final char divide) {
199            this.multiply = multiply;
200            this.divide   = divide;
201        }
202
203        /**
204         * Appends a string that may contains Unicode characters. The enumeration is responsible
205         * for converting the Unicode characters into ASCII ones if needed.
206         */
207        Appendable appendSymbol(final Appendable toAppendTo, final String value) throws IOException {
208            return toAppendTo.append(value);
209        }
210
211        /**
212         * Appends an integer power. The power may be added as an exponent if allowed by the format style.
213         */
214        void appendPower(final Appendable toAppendTo, final int power) throws IOException {
215            if (power >= 0 && power <= 9) {
216                toAppendTo.append(Characters.toSuperScript((char) (power + '0')));
217            } else {
218                toAppendTo.append(String.valueOf(power));
219            }
220        }
221
222        /**
223         * Appends a rational power.
224         */
225        void appendPower(final Appendable toAppendTo, final Fraction power) throws IOException {
226            toAppendTo.append(EXPONENT);
227            final String value = power.toString();
228            if (value.length() == 1) {
229                toAppendTo.append(value);
230            } else {
231                toAppendTo.append(OPEN).append(value).append(CLOSE);
232            }
233        }
234    }
235
236    /**
237     * Symbols or names to use for formatting units in replacement to the default unit symbols or names.
238     * The {@link Unit} instances are the ones specified by user in calls to {@link #label(Unit, String)}.
239     *
240     * @see #label(Unit, String)
241     */
242    private Map<Unit<?>,String> unitToLabel;
243
244    /**
245     * Units associated to a given label (in addition to the system-wide {@link UnitRegistry}).
246     * This map is the converse of {@link #unitToLabel}. The {@link Unit} instances may differ from the ones
247     * specified by user since {@link AbstractUnit#symbol} may have been set to the label specified by the user.
248     * The labels may contain some characters normally not allowed in unit symbols, like white spaces.
249     *
250     * @see #label(Unit, String)
251     */
252    private final Map<String,Unit<?>> labelToUnit;
253
254    /**
255     * The mapping from unit symbols to long localized names.
256     * Those resources are locale-dependent and loaded when first needed.
257     *
258     * @see #symbolToName()
259     */
260    private transient volatile ResourceBundle symbolToName;
261
262    /**
263     * Mapping from long localized and unlocalized names to unit instances.
264     * This map is used only for parsing and created when first needed.
265     *
266     * @see #fromName(String)
267     */
268    private transient volatile Map<String,Unit<?>> nameToUnit;
269
270    /**
271     * Cached values of {@link #nameToUnit}, for avoiding to load the same information many time and for saving memory
272     * if the user create many {@code UnitFormat} instances. Note that we do not cache {@link #symbolToName} because
273     * {@link ResourceBundle} already provides its own caching mechanism.
274     *
275     * @see #fromName(String)
276     */
277    private static final WeakValueHashMap<Locale, Map<String,Unit<?>>> SHARED = new WeakValueHashMap<>(Locale.class);
278
279    /**
280     * Creates the unique {@link #INSTANCE}.
281     */
282    private UnitFormat() {
283        locale      = Locale.ROOT;
284        style       = Style.SYMBOL;
285        unitToLabel = Collections.emptyMap();
286        labelToUnit = Collections.emptyMap();
287    }
288
289    /**
290     * Creates a new format for the given locale.
291     *
292     * @param  locale  the locale to use for parsing and formatting units.
293     */
294    public UnitFormat(final Locale locale) {
295        Objects.requireNonNull(locale);
296        this.locale = locale;
297        style       = Style.SYMBOL;
298        unitToLabel = new HashMap<>();
299        labelToUnit = new HashMap<>();
300    }
301
302    /**
303     * Returns the locale used by this {@code UnitFormat}.
304     *
305     * @return the locale of this {@code UnitFormat}.
306     */
307    public Locale getLocale() {
308        return locale;
309    }
310
311    /**
312     * Sets the locale that this {@code UnitFormat} will use for long names.
313     * For example a call to <code>setLocale({@linkplain Locale#US})</code>
314     * instructs this formatter to use the “meter” spelling instead of “metre”.
315     *
316     * @param  locale  the new locale for this {@code UnitFormat}.
317     *
318     * @see UnitServices#getUnitFormat(String)
319     */
320    public void setLocale(final Locale locale) {
321        Objects.requireNonNull(locale);
322        this.locale  = locale;
323        symbolToName = null;            // Force reloading for the new locale.
324        nameToUnit   = null;
325    }
326
327    /**
328     * Returns whether this {@code UnitFormat} depends on the {@link Locale} given at construction time
329     * for performing its tasks. This method returns {@code true} if formatting long names (e.g. “metre”
330     * or “meter”} and {@code false} if formatting only the unit symbol (e.g. “m”).
331     *
332     * @return {@code true} if formatting depends on the locale.
333     */
334    @Override
335    public boolean isLocaleSensitive() {
336        return style == Style.NAME;
337    }
338
339    /**
340     * Returns whether unit formatting uses ASCII symbols, Unicode symbols or full localized names.
341     *
342     * @return the style of units formatted by this {@code UnitFormat} instance.
343     */
344    public Style getStyle() {
345        return style;
346    }
347
348    /**
349     * Sets whether unit formatting should use ASCII symbols, Unicode symbols or full localized names.
350     *
351     * @param  style  the desired style of units.
352     */
353    public void setStyle(final Style style) {
354        Objects.requireNonNull(style);
355        this.style = style;
356    }
357
358    /**
359     * Attaches a label to the specified unit. A <cite>label</cite> can be a substitute to either the
360     * {@linkplain AbstractUnit#getSymbol() unit symbol} or the {@link AbstractUnit#getName() unit name},
361     * depending on the {@linkplain #getStyle() format style}.
362     * If the specified label is already associated to another unit, then the previous association is discarded.
363     *
364     * <h4>Restriction on character set</h4>
365     * Current implementation accepts only {@linkplain Character#isLetter(int) letters},
366     * {@linkplain Characters#isSubScript(int) subscripts}, {@linkplain Character#isSpaceChar(int) spaces}
367     * (including non-breaking spaces but not CR/LF characters),
368     * the degree sign (°) and a few other characters like underscore.
369     * The set of legal characters may be expanded in future Seshat versions,
370     * but the following restrictions are likely to remain:
371     *
372     * <ul>
373     *   <li>The following characters are reserved since they have special meaning in UCUM format, in URI
374     *       or in Seshat parser: <blockquote>" # ( ) * + - . / : = ? [ ] { } ^ ⋅ ∕</blockquote></li>
375     *   <li>The symbol can not begin or end with digits, since such digits would be confused with unit power.</li>
376     * </ul>
377     *
378     * @param  unit   the unit being labeled.
379     * @param  label  the new label for the given unit.
380     * @throws IllegalArgumentException if the given label is not a valid unit name.
381     */
382    @Override
383    public void label(final Unit<?> unit, String label) {
384        Objects.requireNonNull(unit);
385        label = label.trim();
386        for (int i=0; i < label.length();) {
387            final int c = label.codePointAt(i);
388            if (!AbstractUnit.isSymbolChar(c) && !Character.isSpaceChar(c)) {       // NOT Character.isWhitespace(int)
389                throw new IllegalArgumentException(Errors.format(Errors.Keys.IllegalArgumentValue_2, "label", label));
390            }
391            i += Character.charCount(c);
392        }
393        Unit<?> labeledUnit = unit;
394        if (labeledUnit instanceof ConventionalUnit<?>) {
395            labeledUnit = ((ConventionalUnit<?>) labeledUnit).forSymbol(label);
396        }
397        final Unit<?> unitForOldLabel = labelToUnit.remove(unitToLabel.put(unit, label));
398        final Unit<?> oldUnitForLabel = labelToUnit.put(label, labeledUnit);
399        if (oldUnitForLabel != null && !oldUnitForLabel.equals(labeledUnit) && !label.equals(unitToLabel.remove(oldUnitForLabel))) {
400            /*
401             * Assuming there is no bug in our algorithm, this exception should never happen
402             * unless this UnitFormat has been modified concurrently in another thread.
403             */
404            throw new ConcurrentModificationException("unitToLabel");
405        }
406        if (unitForOldLabel != null && !unitForOldLabel.getSystemUnit().equals(unit.getSystemUnit())) {
407            /*
408             * Assuming there is no bug in our algorithm, this exception should never happen
409             * unless this UnitFormat has been modified concurrently in another thread.
410             * We compared system units because the units may not be strictly equal
411             * as a result of the call to ConventionalUnit.forSymbol(label).
412             */
413            throw new ConcurrentModificationException("labelToUnit");
414        }
415    }
416
417    /**
418     * Loads the {@code UnitNames} resource bundle for the given locale.
419     */
420    static ResourceBundle getBundle(final Locale locale) {
421        return ResourceBundle.getBundle("tech.uom.seshat.UnitNames", locale, UnitFormat.class.getClassLoader());
422    }
423
424    /**
425     * Returns the mapping from unit symbols to long localized names.
426     * This mapping is loaded when first needed and memorized as long as the locale does not change.
427     */
428    private ResourceBundle symbolToName() {
429        ResourceBundle r = symbolToName;
430        if (r == null) {
431            symbolToName = r = getBundle(locale);
432        }
433        return r;
434    }
435
436    /**
437     * Returns the unit instance for the given long (un)localized name.
438     * This method is somewhat the converse of {@link #symbolToName()}, but recognizes also
439     * international and American spelling of unit names in addition of localized names.
440     * The intent is to recognize "meter" as well as "metre".
441     *
442     * <p>While we said that {@code UnitFormat} is not thread safe, we make an exception for this method
443     * for allowing the singleton {@link #INSTANCE} to parse symbols in a multi-threads environment.</p>
444     *
445     * @param  uom  the unit symbol, without leading or trailing spaces.
446     * @return the unit for the given name, or {@code null} if unknown.
447     */
448    private Unit<?> fromName(String uom) {
449        /*
450         * Before to search in resource bundles, check for degrees units. The "deg" unit can be both angular
451         * and Celsius degrees. We try to resolve this ambiguity by looking for the "C" suffix. We perform a
452         * special case for the degrees units because SI symbols are case-sentive and unit names in resource
453         * bundles are case-insensitive, but the "deg" case is a mix of both.
454         */
455        final int length = uom.length();
456        for (int i=0; ; i++) {
457            if (i != DEGREES.length()) {
458                if (i != length && (uom.charAt(i) | ('a' - 'A')) == DEGREES.charAt(i)) {
459                    continue;                           // Loop as long as the characters are the same, ignoring case.
460                }
461                if (i != 3 && i != 6) {
462                    break;                              // Exit if not "deg" (3) or "degree" (6 characters).
463                }
464            }
465            if (length == i) {
466                return Units.DEGREE;                    // Exactly "deg", "degree" or "degrees" (ignoring case).
467            }
468            final int c = uom.codePointAt(i);
469            if (c == '_' || Character.isSpaceChar(c)) {
470                i += Character.charCount(c);            // Ignore space in "degree C", "deg C", "deg K", etc.
471            }
472            if (length - i == 1) {
473                switch (uom.charAt(i)) {
474                    case 'K':                           // Unicode U+212A
475                    case 'K': return Units.KELVIN;      // "degK" (ignoring case except for 'K')
476                    case 'C': return Units.CELSIUS;
477                    case 'N':                           // degree_N, degrees_N, degreeN, degreesN.
478                    case 'E': return Units.DEGREE;      // degree_E, degrees_E, degreeE, degreesE.
479                }
480            }
481            break;
482        }
483        /*
484         * At this point, we determined that the given unit symbol is not degrees (of angle or of temperature).
485         * Remaining code is generic to all other kinds of units: a check in a HashMap loaded when first needed.
486         */
487        Map<String,Unit<?>> map = nameToUnit;
488        if (map == null) {
489            map = SHARED.get(locale);
490            if (map == null) {
491                map = new HashMap<>(128);
492                copy(locale, symbolToName(), map);
493                if (!locale.equals(Locale.US))   copy(Locale.US,   getBundle(Locale.US),   map);
494                if (!locale.equals(Locale.ROOT)) copy(Locale.ROOT, getBundle(Locale.ROOT), map);
495                /*
496                 * The UnitAliases file contains names that are not unit symbols and are not included in the UnitNames
497                 * property files neither. It contains longer names sometime used (for example "decimal degree" instead
498                 * of "degree"), some plural forms (for example "feet" instead of "foot") and a few common misspellings
499                 * (for exemple "Celcius" instead of "Celsius").
500                 */
501                final ResourceBundle r = ResourceBundle.getBundle("tech.uom.seshat.UnitAliases", locale, UnitFormat.class.getClassLoader());
502                for (final String name : r.keySet()) {
503                    map.put(name.intern(), Units.get(r.getString(name)));
504                }
505                map = Collections.unmodifiableMap(map);
506                /*
507                 * Cache the map so we can share it with other UnitFormat instances.
508                 * Sharing is safe if the map is unmodifiable.
509                 */
510                synchronized (SHARED) {
511                    for (final Map<String,Unit<?>> existing : SHARED.values()) {
512                        if (map.equals(existing)) {
513                            map = existing;
514                            break;
515                        }
516                    }
517                    SHARED.put(locale, map);
518                }
519            }
520            nameToUnit = map;
521        }
522        /*
523         * The 'nameToUnit' map contains plural forms (declared in UnitAliases.properties),
524         * but we make a special case for "degrees", "metres" and "meters" because they
525         * appear in numerous places.
526         */
527        uom = uom.replace('_', ' ').toLowerCase(locale);
528        uom = CharSequences.replace(CharSequences.replace(CharSequences.replace(CharSequences.toASCII(uom),
529                "meters",  "meter"),
530                "metres",  "metre"),
531                 DEGREES,  "degree").toString();
532        /*
533         * Returns the unit with application of the power if it is part of the name.
534         * For example this method interprets "meter2" as "meter" raised to power 2.
535         */
536        Unit<?> unit = map.get(uom);
537appPow: if (unit == null) {
538            int s = uom.length();
539            if (--s > 0 && isDigit(uom.charAt(s))) {
540                do if (--s < 0) break appPow;
541                while (isDigit(uom.charAt(s)));
542                if (uom.charAt(s) == '-') {
543                    if (--s < 0) break appPow;
544                }
545                unit = map.get(uom.substring(0, ++s));
546                if (unit != null) {
547                    unit = unit.pow(Integer.parseInt(uom.substring(s)));
548                }
549            }
550        }
551        return unit;
552    }
553
554    /**
555     * Copies all entries from the given "symbols to names" mapping to the given "names to units" mapping.
556     * During this copy, keys are converted from symbols to names and values are converted from symbols to
557     * {@code Unit} instance. We use {@code Unit} values instead of their symbols because all {@code Unit}
558     * instances are created at {@link Units} class initialization anyway (so we do not create new instance
559     * here), and it avoid to retain references to the {@link String} instances loaded by the resource bundle.
560     */
561    private static void copy(final Locale locale, final ResourceBundle symbolToName, final Map<String,Unit<?>> nameToUnit) {
562        for (final String symbol : symbolToName.keySet()) {
563            nameToUnit.put(CharSequences.toASCII(symbolToName.getString(symbol).toLowerCase(locale)).toString().intern(), Units.get(symbol));
564        }
565    }
566
567    /**
568     * Formats the specified unit.
569     * This method performs the first of the following actions that can be done.
570     *
571     * <ol>
572     *   <li>If a {@linkplain #label(Unit, String) label has been specified} for the given unit,
573     *       then that label is appended unconditionally.</li>
574     *   <li>Otherwise if the formatting style is {@link Style#NAME} and the {@link Unit#getName()} method
575     *       returns a non-null value, then that value is appended. {@code Unit} instances implemented by
576     *       Seshat are handled in a special way for localizing the name according the
577     *       {@linkplain #setLocale(Locale) locale specified to this format}.</li>
578     *   <li>Otherwise if the {@link Unit#getSymbol()} method returns a non-null value,
579     *       then that value is appended.</li>
580     *   <li>Otherwise a default symbol is created from the entries returned by {@link Unit#getBaseUnits()}.</li>
581     * </ol>
582     *
583     * @param  unit        the unit to format.
584     * @param  toAppendTo  where to format the unit.
585     * @return the given {@code toAppendTo} argument, for method calls chaining.
586     * @throws IOException if an error occurred while writing to the destination.
587     */
588    @Override
589    public Appendable format(final Unit<?> unit, final Appendable toAppendTo) throws IOException {
590        Objects.requireNonNull(unit);
591        Objects.requireNonNull(toAppendTo);
592        /*
593         * Choice 1: label specified by a call to label(Unit, String).
594         */
595        {
596            final String label = unitToLabel.get(unit);
597            if (label != null) {
598                return toAppendTo.append(label);
599            }
600        }
601        /*
602         * Choice 2: value specified by Unit.getName(). We skip this check if the given Unit is an instance
603         * implemented by Seshat because  AbstractUnit.getName()  delegates to the same resource bundle
604         * than the one used by this block. We are better to use the resource bundle of the UnitFormat both
605         * for performance reasons and because the locale may not be the same.
606         */
607        if (style == Style.NAME) {
608            if (!(unit instanceof AbstractUnit)) {
609                final String label = unit.getName();
610                if (label != null) {
611                    return toAppendTo.append(label);
612                }
613            } else {
614                String label = unit.getSymbol();
615                if (label != null) {
616                    if (label.isEmpty()) {
617                        label = UNITY;
618                    }
619                    // Following is not thread-safe, but it is okay since we do not use INSTANCE for unit names.
620                    final ResourceBundle names = symbolToName();
621                    try {
622                        label = names.getString(label);
623                    } catch (MissingResourceException e) {
624                        // Name not found; use the symbol as a fallback.
625                    }
626                    return toAppendTo.append(label);
627                }
628            }
629        }
630        /*
631         * Choice 3: if the unit has a specific symbol, appends that symbol.
632         * Seshat implementation uses Unicode characters in the symbol, which are not valid for UCUM.
633         * But Styme.UCUM.appendSymbol(…) performs required replacements.
634         */
635        {
636            final String symbol = unit.getSymbol();
637            if (symbol != null) {
638                return style.appendSymbol(toAppendTo, symbol);
639            }
640        }
641        /*
642         * Choice 4: if all the above failed, fallback on a symbol created from the base units and their power.
643         * Note that this may produce more verbose symbols than needed because derived units like Volt or Watt
644         * are decomposed into their base SI units. The scale factor will be inserted before the unit components,
645         * e.g. "30⋅m∕s". Note that a scale factor relative to system unit may not be what we want if the unit
646         * contains "kg", since it block us from using SI prefixes. But in many cases (not all), a symbol will
647         * have been created by SystemUnit.transform(…), in which case "Choice 3" above would have been executed.
648         */
649        final Unit<?> unscaled = unit.getSystemUnit();
650        @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")          // Both 'unit' and 'unscaled' are 'Unit<Q>'.
651        final double scale = AbstractConverter.scale(unit.getConverterTo((Unit) unscaled));
652        if (Double.isNaN(scale)) {
653            throw new IllegalArgumentException(Errors.format(Errors.Keys.NonRatioUnit_1,
654                    "?⋅" + Style.OPEN + unscaled + Style.CLOSE));
655        }
656        /*
657         * In addition of the scale, we will need to know:
658         *
659         *   - The components (for example "m" and "s" in "m∕s").
660         *   - Whether we have at least one component on the left side of "∕" operation.
661         *     Used for determining if we should prepend "1" before the "∕" symbol.
662         *   - If there is exactly one component on the left side of "∕" and that component
663         *     is prefixable, the power raising that component. Used for choosing a prefix.
664         */
665        int prefixPower = 0;
666        boolean hasNumerator = false;
667        final Map<? extends Unit<?>, ? extends Number> components;
668        if (unscaled instanceof AbstractUnit<?>) {
669            // In Seshat implementation, power may be fractional.
670            final Map<SystemUnit<?>, Fraction> c = ((AbstractUnit<?>) unscaled).getBaseSystemUnits();
671            components = c;
672            for (final Map.Entry<SystemUnit<?>, Fraction> e : c.entrySet()) {
673                final Fraction power = e.getValue();
674                if (power.signum() > 0) {
675                    hasNumerator = true;
676                    if (prefixPower == 0 && power.denominator == 1 && e.getKey().isPrefixable()) {
677                        prefixPower = power.numerator;
678                    } else {
679                        prefixPower = 0;
680                        break;
681                    }
682                }
683            }
684        } else {
685            // Fallback for foreigner implementations (power restricted to integer).
686            Map<? extends Unit<?>, Integer> c = unscaled.getBaseUnits();
687            if (c == null) c = Collections.singletonMap(unit, 1);
688            components = c;
689            for (final Map.Entry<? extends Unit<?>, Integer> e : c.entrySet()) {
690                final int power = e.getValue();
691                if (power > 0) {
692                    hasNumerator = true;
693                    if (prefixPower == 0 && AbstractUnit.isPrefixable(e.getKey())) {
694                        prefixPower = power;
695                    } else {
696                        prefixPower = 0;
697                        break;
698                    }
699                }
700            }
701        }
702        /*
703         * Append the scale factor. If we can use a prefix (e.g. "km" instead of "1000⋅m"), we will do that.
704         * Otherwise if the scale is a power of 10 and we are allowed to use Unicode symbols, we will write
705         * for example 10⁵⋅m instead of 100000⋅m. If the scale is not a power of 10, or if we are requested
706         * to format UCUM symbol, then we fallback on the usual 'Double.toString(double)' representation.
707         */
708        if (scale != 1) {
709            final char prefix = Prefixes.symbol(scale, prefixPower);
710            if (prefix != 0) {
711                toAppendTo.append(Prefixes.concat(prefix, ""));
712            } else {
713                boolean asPowerOf10 = (style != Style.UCUM);
714                if (asPowerOf10) {
715                    double power = Math.log10(scale);
716                    asPowerOf10 = AbstractConverter.epsilonEquals(power, power = Math.round(power));
717                    if (asPowerOf10) {
718                        toAppendTo.append("10");
719                        final String text = Integer.toString((int) power);
720                        for (int i=0; i<text.length(); i++) {
721                            toAppendTo.append(Characters.toSuperScript(text.charAt(i)));
722                        }
723                    }
724                }
725                if (!asPowerOf10) {
726                    final String text = Double.toString(scale);
727                    int length = text.length();
728                    if (text.endsWith(".0")) length -= 2;
729                    toAppendTo.append(text, 0, length);
730                }
731                /*
732                 * The 'formatComponents' method appends division symbol only, no multiplication symbol.
733                 * If we have formatted a scale factor and there is at least one component to multiply,
734                 * we need to append the multiplication symbol ourselves. Note that 'formatComponents'
735                 * put numerators before denominators, so we are sure that the first term after the
736                 * multiplication symbol is a numerator.
737                 */
738                if (hasNumerator) {
739                    toAppendTo.append(style.multiply);
740                }
741            }
742        } else if (!hasNumerator) {
743            toAppendTo.append('1');
744        }
745        formatComponents(components, style, toAppendTo);
746        return toAppendTo;
747    }
748
749    /**
750     * Creates a new symbol (e.g. "m/s") from the given symbols and factors.
751     * Keys in the given map can be either {@link Unit} or {@link Dimension} instances.
752     * Values in the given map are either {@link Integer} or {@link Fraction} instances.
753     *
754     * @param  components  the components of the symbol to format.
755     * @param  style       whether to allow Unicode characters.
756     * @param  toAppendTo  where to write the symbol.
757     */
758    static void formatComponents(final Map<?, ? extends Number> components, final Style style, final Appendable toAppendTo)
759            throws IOException
760    {
761        boolean isFirst = true;
762        final List<Map.Entry<?,? extends Number>> deferred = new ArrayList<>(components.size());
763        for (final Map.Entry<?,? extends Number> entry : components.entrySet()) {
764            final Number power = entry.getValue();
765            final int n = (power instanceof Fraction) ? ((Fraction) power).numerator : power.intValue();
766            if (n > 0) {
767                if (!isFirst) {
768                    toAppendTo.append(style.multiply);
769                }
770                isFirst = false;
771                formatComponent(entry, false, style, toAppendTo);
772            } else if (n != 0) {
773                deferred.add(entry);
774            }
775        }
776        /*
777         * At this point, all numerators have been appended. Now append the denominators together.
778         * For example pressure dimension is formatted as M∕(L⋅T²) no matter if 'M' was the first
779         * dimension in the given 'components' map or not.
780         */
781        if (!deferred.isEmpty()) {
782            toAppendTo.append(style.divide);
783            final boolean useParenthesis = (deferred.size() > 1);
784            if (useParenthesis) {
785                toAppendTo.append(Style.OPEN);
786            }
787            isFirst = true;
788            for (final Map.Entry<?,? extends Number> entry : deferred) {
789                if (!isFirst) {
790                    toAppendTo.append(style.multiply);
791                }
792                isFirst = false;
793                formatComponent(entry, true, style, toAppendTo);
794            }
795            if (useParenthesis) {
796                toAppendTo.append(Style.CLOSE);
797            }
798        }
799    }
800
801    /**
802     * Formats a single unit or dimension raised to the given power.
803     *
804     * @param  entry    the base unit or base dimension to format, together with its power.
805     * @param  inverse  {@code true} for inverting the power sign.
806     * @param  style    whether to allow Unicode characters.
807     */
808    private static void formatComponent(final Map.Entry<?,? extends Number> entry, final boolean inverse,
809            final Style style, final Appendable toAppendTo) throws IOException
810    {
811        formatSymbol(entry.getKey(), style, toAppendTo);
812        final Number power = entry.getValue();
813        int n;
814        if (power instanceof Fraction) {
815            Fraction f = (Fraction) power;
816            if (f.denominator != 1) {
817                if (inverse) {
818                    f = f.negate();
819                }
820                style.appendPower(toAppendTo, f);
821                return;
822            }
823            n = f.numerator;
824        } else {
825            n = power.intValue();
826        }
827        if (inverse) n = -n;
828        if (n != 1) {
829            style.appendPower(toAppendTo, n);
830        }
831    }
832
833    /**
834     * Appends the symbol for the given base unit of base dimension, or "?" if no symbol was found.
835     * If the given object is a unit, then it should be an instance of {@link SystemUnit}.
836     *
837     * @param  base        the base unit or base dimension to format.
838     * @param  style       whether to allow Unicode characters.
839     * @param  toAppendTo  where to append the symbol.
840     */
841    private static void formatSymbol(final Object base, final Style style, final Appendable toAppendTo) throws IOException {
842        if (base instanceof UnitDimension) {
843            final char symbol = ((UnitDimension) base).symbol;
844            if (symbol != 0) {
845                toAppendTo.append(symbol);
846                return;
847            }
848        }
849        if (base instanceof Unit<?>) {
850            final String symbol = ((Unit<?>) base).getSymbol();
851            if (symbol != null) {
852                style.appendSymbol(toAppendTo, symbol);
853                return;
854            }
855        }
856        toAppendTo.append('?');
857    }
858
859    /**
860     * Formats the specified unit in the given buffer.
861     * This method delegates to {@link #format(Unit, Appendable)}.
862     *
863     * @param  unit        the unit to format.
864     * @param  toAppendTo  where to format the unit.
865     * @param  pos         where to store the position of a formatted field, or {@code null} if none.
866     * @return the given {@code toAppendTo} argument, for method calls chaining.
867     */
868    @Override
869    public StringBuffer format(final Object unit, final StringBuffer toAppendTo, final FieldPosition pos) {
870        try {
871            return (StringBuffer) format((Unit<?>) unit, toAppendTo);
872        } catch (IOException e) {
873            throw new UncheckedIOException(e);          // Should never happen since we are writting to a StringBuffer.
874        }
875    }
876
877    /**
878     * Formats the given unit.
879     * This method delegates to {@link #format(Unit, Appendable)}.
880     *
881     * @param  unit  the unit to format.
882     * @return the formatted unit.
883     */
884    @Override
885    public String format(final Unit<?> unit) {
886        try {
887            return format(unit, new StringBuilder()).toString();
888        } catch (IOException e) {
889            throw new UncheckedIOException(e);      // Should never happen since we are writting to a StringBuilder.
890        }
891    }
892
893    /**
894     * Returns {@code 0} or {@code 1} if the {@code '*'} character at the given index stands for exponentiation
895     * instead of multiplication, or a negative value if the character stands for multiplication. This check
896     * is used for heuristic rules at parsing time. Current implementation applies the following rules:
897     *
898     * <ul>
899     *   <li>The operation is presumed an exponentiation if the '*' symbol is doubled, as in {@code "m**s-1"}.</li>
900     *   <li>The operation is presumed an exponentiation if it is surrounded by digits or a sign on its right side.
901     *       Example: {@code "10*-6"}, which means 1E-6 in UCUM syntax.</li>
902     *   <li>All other cases are currently presumed multiplication.
903     *       Example: {@code "m*s"}.</li>
904     * </ul>
905     *
906     * @return -1 for parsing as a multiplication, or a positive value for exponentiation.
907     *         If positive, this is the number of characters in the exponent symbol minus 1.
908     */
909    private static int exponentOperator(final CharSequence symbols, int i, final int length) {
910        if (i >= 0 && ++i < length) {
911            final char c = symbols.charAt(i);           // No need for code point because next conditions are true only in BMP.
912            if (c == Style.EXPONENT_OR_MULTIPLY) {
913                return 1;                               // "**" operator: need to skip one character after '*'.
914            }
915            if ((isDigit(c) || isSign(c)) && isDigit(symbols.charAt(i-2))) {
916                return 0;                               // "*" operator surrounded by digits: no character to skip.
917            }
918        }
919        return -1;
920    }
921
922    /**
923     * Returns {@code true} if the {@code '.'} character at the given index is surrounded by digits or
924     * is at the beginning or the end of the character sequences. This check is used for heuristic rules.
925     *
926     * @see Style#UCUM
927     */
928    private static boolean isDecimalSeparator(final CharSequence symbols, int i, final int length) {
929        return (i   == 0      || isDigit(symbols.charAt(i-1)) &&
930               (++i >= length || isDigit(symbols.charAt(i))));
931    }
932
933    /**
934     * Returns {@code true} if the given character is a digit in the sense of the {@code UnitFormat} parser.
935     * Note that "digit" is taken here in a much more restrictive way than {@link Character#isDigit(int)}.
936     *
937     * <p>A return value of {@code true} guarantees that the given character is in the Basic Multilingual Plane (BMP).
938     * Consequently the {@code c} argument value does not need to be the result of {@link String#codePointAt(int)};
939     * the result of {@link String#charAt(int)} is sufficient. We nevertheless use the {@code int} type for avoiding
940     * the need to cast if caller uses code points for another reason.</p>
941     *
942     * @see Character#isBmpCodePoint(int)
943     */
944    private static boolean isDigit(final int c) {
945        return c >= '0' && c <= '9';
946    }
947
948    /**
949     * Returns {@code true} if the given character is the sign of a number according the {@code UnitFormat} parser.
950     * A return value of {@code true} guarantees that the given character is in the Basic Multilingual Plane (BMP).
951     * Consequently the {@code c} argument value does not need to be the result of {@link String#codePointAt(int)}.
952     */
953    private static boolean isSign(final int c) {
954        return c == '+' || c == '-';
955    }
956
957    /**
958     * Returns {@code true} if the given character is the sign of a division operator.
959     * A return value of {@code true} guarantees that the given character is in the Basic Multilingual Plane (BMP).
960     * Consequently the {@code c} argument value does not need to be the result of {@link String#codePointAt(int)}.
961     */
962    private static boolean isDivisor(final int c) {
963        return c == '/' || c == AbstractUnit.DIVIDE;
964    }
965
966    /**
967     * Returns {@code true} if the given character sequence contains at least one digit.
968     * This is a hack for allowing to recognize units like "100 feet" (in principle not
969     * legal, but seen in practice). This verification has some value if digits are not
970     * allowed as unit label or symbol.
971     */
972    private static boolean hasDigit(final CharSequence symbol, int lower, final int upper) {
973        while (lower < upper) {
974            if (isDigit(symbol.charAt(lower++))) {
975                return true;
976            }
977        }
978        return false;
979    }
980
981    /**
982     * Parse position when text to be parsed is expected to contain nothing else than a unit symbol.
983     * This is used for recording whether another term (separated from the previous term by a space)
984     * is allowed or not.
985     */
986    private static final class Position extends ParsePosition {
987        /** {@code true} if we do not expect any more content after the last term parsed. */
988        boolean finished;
989
990        /** Creates a new position initialized to the beginning of the text to parse. */
991        Position() {
992            super(0);
993        }
994    }
995
996    /**
997     * Reports that the parsing is finished and no more content should be parsed.
998     * This method is invoked when the last parsed term is possibly one or more words instead of unit symbols.
999     * The intent is to avoid trying to parse "degree minute" as "degree × minute". By contrast, this method is
1000     * not invoked if the string to parse is "m kg**-2" because it can be interpreted as "m × kg**-2".
1001     */
1002    private static void finish(final ParsePosition pos) {
1003        if (pos instanceof Position) {
1004            ((Position) pos).finished = true;
1005        }
1006    }
1007
1008    /**
1009     * Parses the given text as an instance of {@code Unit}.
1010     * If the parse completes without reading the entire length of the text, an exception is thrown.
1011     *
1012     * <p>The parsing is lenient: symbols can be products or quotients of units like “m∕s”,
1013     * or words like “meters per second”.
1014     * The product operator can be either {@code '.'} (ASCII) or {@code '⋅'} (Unicode) character.
1015     * Exponent after symbol can be decimal digits as in “m2” or a superscript as in “m²”.</p>
1016     *
1017     * <p>This method differs from {@link #parse(CharSequence, ParsePosition)} in the treatment of white spaces:
1018     * that method with a {@link ParsePosition} argument stops parsing at the first white space,
1019     * while this {@code parse(…)} method treats white spaces as multiplications.
1020     * The reason for this difference is that white space is normally not a valid multiplication symbol;
1021     * it could be followed by a text which is not part of the unit symbol.
1022     * But in the case of this {@code parse(CharSequence)} method, the whole {@code CharSequence} shall be a unit symbol.
1023     * In such case, white spaces are less ambiguous.</p>
1024     *
1025     * <p>The default implementation delegates to
1026     * <code>{@linkplain #parse(CharSequence, ParsePosition) parse}(symbols, new ParsePosition(0))</code>
1027     * and verifies that all non-white characters have been parsed.
1028     * Units separated by spaces are multiplied; for example "kg m**-2" is parsed as kg/m².</p>
1029     *
1030     * @param  symbols  the unit symbols or URI to parse.
1031     * @return the unit parsed from the specified symbols.
1032     * @throws ParserException if a problem occurred while parsing the given symbols.
1033     *
1034     * @see Units#valueOf(String)
1035     */
1036    @Override
1037    public Unit<?> parse(final CharSequence symbols) throws ParserException {
1038        final Position position = new Position();
1039        Unit<?> unit = parse(symbols, position);
1040        final int length = symbols.length();
1041        int unrecognized;
1042        while ((unrecognized = CharSequences.skipLeadingWhitespaces(symbols, position.getIndex(), length)) < length) {
1043            if (position.finished || !Character.isLetter(Character.codePointAt(symbols, unrecognized))) {
1044                throw new ParserException(Errors.format(Errors.Keys.UnexpectedCharactersAfter_2,
1045                        CharSequences.trimWhitespaces(symbols, 0, unrecognized),
1046                        CharSequences.trimWhitespaces(symbols, unrecognized, length)),
1047                        symbols, unrecognized);
1048            }
1049            position.setIndex(unrecognized);
1050            unit = unit.multiply(parse(symbols, position));
1051        }
1052        return unit;
1053    }
1054
1055    /**
1056     * Parses a portion of the given text as an instance of {@code Unit}.
1057     * Parsing begins at the index given by {@link ParsePosition#getIndex()}.
1058     * After parsing, the above-cited index is updated to the first unparsed character.
1059     *
1060     * <p>The parsing is lenient: symbols can be products or quotients of units like “m∕s”,
1061     * or words like “meters per second”.
1062     * The product operator can be either {@code '.'} (ASCII) or {@code '⋅'} (Unicode) character.
1063     * Exponent after symbol can be decimal digits as in “m2” or a superscript as in “m²”.</p>
1064     *
1065     * <p>Note that contrarily to {@link #parseObject(String, ParsePosition)}, this method never return {@code null}.
1066     * If an error occurs at parsing time, an unchecked {@link ParserException} is thrown.</p>
1067     *
1068     * @param  symbols  the unit symbols to parse.
1069     * @param  position on input, index of the first character to parse.
1070     *                  On output, index after the last parsed character.
1071     * @return the unit parsed from the specified symbols.
1072     * @throws ParserException if a problem occurred while parsing the given symbols.
1073     */
1074    @SuppressWarnings({"null", "fallthrough"})
1075    public Unit<?> parse(CharSequence symbols, final ParsePosition position) throws ParserException {
1076        Objects.requireNonNull(symbols);
1077        Objects.requireNonNull(position);
1078        int end   = symbols.length();
1079        int start = CharSequences.skipLeadingWhitespaces(symbols, position.getIndex(), end);
1080        /*
1081         * Split the unit around the multiplication and division operators and parse each term individually.
1082         * Note that exponentation need to be kept as part of a single unit symbol.
1083         *
1084         * The 'start' variable is the index of the first character of the next unit term to parse.
1085         */
1086        final Operation operation = new Operation(symbols);    // Enumeration value: NOOP, IMPLICIT, MULTIPLY, DIVIDE.
1087        Unit<?> unit = null;
1088        boolean hasSpaces = false;
1089        int i = start;
1090scan:   for (int n; i < end; i += n) {
1091            final int c = Character.codePointAt(symbols, i);
1092            n = Character.charCount(c);
1093            final int next;
1094            switch (c) {
1095                /*
1096                 * The minus sign can be both part of a number or part of a symbol. If the minus sign if followed
1097                 * by a digit, then handle it as part of a number, in which case the action is only "continue".
1098                 * Otherwise handle as part of a symbol, in which case the action is in the default case below.
1099                 * The intent is to prevent the replacement of Operation.IMPLICIT by Operation.MULTIPLY in symbol
1100                 * like "(m²⋅s)-1" because we want the "-1" part to be handled as Operation.EXPONENT instead.
1101                 */
1102                case '-': {
1103                    if (i + n < end && Character.isDigit(Character.codePointAt(symbols, i + n))) {
1104                        continue;
1105                    }
1106                    // else fall through.
1107                }
1108                /*
1109                 * For any character that is not an operator or parenthesis, either continue the scanning of
1110                 * characters or stop it, depending on whether the character is valid for a unit symbol or not.
1111                 * In the later case, we consider that we reached the end of a unit symbol.
1112                 */
1113                default:  {
1114                    if (AbstractUnit.isSymbolChar(c)) {
1115                        if (operation.code == Operation.IMPLICIT) {
1116                            operation.code =  Operation.MULTIPLY;
1117                        }
1118                        continue;
1119                    }
1120                    if (Character.isDigit(c) || Characters.isSuperScript(c)) {
1121                        continue;
1122                    }
1123                    if (Character.isSpaceChar(c)) {                         // NOT Character.isWhitespace(int)
1124                        hasSpaces = true;
1125                        continue;
1126                    }
1127                    break scan;
1128                }
1129                /*
1130                 * Star is for exponentiation in UCUM syntax, but some symbols may use it for unit multiplication.
1131                 * We interpret the symbol as a multiplication if the characters before or after it seem to be for
1132                 * a unit symbol.
1133                 */
1134                case Style.EXPONENT_OR_MULTIPLY: {
1135                    final int w = exponentOperator(symbols, i, end);
1136                    if (w < 0) {
1137                        next = Operation.MULTIPLY;
1138                        break;
1139                    }
1140                    i += w;
1141                    // else fall through.
1142                }
1143                case Style.EXPONENT: {
1144                    if (operation.code == Operation.IMPLICIT) {
1145                        next = Operation.EXPONENT;
1146                        break;
1147                    }
1148                    continue;
1149                }
1150                /*
1151                 * The period is the multiplication operator in UCUM format. According UCUM there is no ambiguity
1152                 * with the decimal separator since unit terms should not contain floating point numbers. However
1153                 * we relax this rule in order to support scale factor of angular units (e.g. π/180).  The period
1154                 * is interpreted as a decimal separator if there is a decimal digit before and after it.
1155                 */
1156                case '.': if (isDecimalSeparator(symbols, i, end)) continue;
1157                case '×': // Fall through
1158                case AbstractUnit.MULTIPLY: next = Operation.MULTIPLY; break;
1159                case '÷':
1160                case '⁄': // Fraction slash
1161                case '/':
1162                case AbstractUnit.DIVIDE: next = Operation.DIVIDE; break;
1163                /*
1164                 * If we find an '(' parenthesis, invoke recursively this method for the part inside parenthesis.
1165                 * The parsing should end at the ')' parenthesis since it is not a valid unit symbol. If we do not
1166                 * find that closing parenthesis, this will be considered an error.
1167                 */
1168                case Style.OPEN: {
1169                    final int pos = i + Character.charCount(c);
1170                    final ParsePosition sub = new ParsePosition(pos);
1171                    final Unit<?> term = parse(symbols, sub);
1172                    i = CharSequences.skipLeadingWhitespaces(symbols, sub.getIndex(), end);
1173                    if (i >= end || Character.codePointAt(symbols, i) != Style.CLOSE) {
1174                        throw new ParserException(Errors.format(Errors.Keys.NonEquilibratedParenthesis_2,
1175                               symbols.subSequence(start, i), Style.CLOSE), symbols, start);
1176                    }
1177                    unit = operation.apply(unit, term, pos);
1178                    operation.code = Operation.IMPLICIT;    // Default operation if there is no × or / symbols after parenthesis.
1179                    start = i + (n = 1);                    // Skip the number of characters in the '(' Unicode code point.
1180                    continue;
1181                }
1182            }
1183            /*
1184             * We reach this point only if we found some operator (division or multiplication).
1185             * If the operator has been found between two digits, we consider it as part of the
1186             * term. For example "m2/3" is considered as a single term where "2/3" is the exponent.
1187             */
1188            if (i > start && i+n < end
1189                    && Character.isDigit(Character.codePointBefore(symbols, i))
1190                    && Character.isDigit(Character.codePointAt(symbols, i+n)))
1191            {
1192                continue;
1193            }
1194            /*
1195             * At this point, we have either a first unit to parse (NOOP), or a multiplication or division to apply
1196             * between the previously parsed units and the next unit to parse. A special case is IMPLICIT, which is
1197             * a multiplication without explicit × symbol after the parenthesis. The implicit multiplication can be
1198             * overridden by an explicit × or / symbol, which is what happened if we reach this point (tip: look in
1199             * the above 'switch' statement all cases that end with 'break', not 'break scan' or 'continue').
1200             */
1201            if (operation.code != Operation.IMPLICIT) {
1202                unit = operation.apply(unit, parseTerm(symbols, start, i, operation), start);
1203            }
1204            hasSpaces = false;
1205            operation.code = next;
1206            start = i + n;
1207        }
1208        /*
1209         * At this point we either found an unrecognized character or reached the end of string. We will
1210         * parse the remaining characters as a unit and apply the pending unit operation (multiplication
1211         * or division). But before, we need to check if the parsing should stop at the first whitespace.
1212         * This verification assumes that spaces are allowed only in labels specified by the label(…)
1213         * method and in resource bundles, not in labels specified by AbstractUnit.alternate(String).
1214         */
1215        Unit<?> component = null;
1216        if (hasSpaces) {
1217            end = i;
1218            start = CharSequences.skipLeadingWhitespaces(symbols, start, i);
1219search:     while ((i = CharSequences.skipTrailingWhitespaces(symbols, start, i)) > start) {
1220                final String uom = symbols.subSequence(start, i).toString();
1221                if ((component = labelToUnit.get(uom)) != null) break;
1222                if ((component =        fromName(uom)) != null) break;
1223                int j=i, c;
1224                do {
1225                    c = Character.codePointBefore(symbols, j);
1226                    j -= Character.charCount(c);
1227                    if (j <= start) break search;
1228                } while (!Character.isWhitespace(c));
1229                /*
1230                 * Really use Character.isWhitespace(c) above, not Character.isSpaceChar(c), because we want
1231                 * to exclude non-breaking spaces.   This block should be the only place in UnitFormat class
1232                 * where we use isWhitespace(c) instead of isSpaceChar(c).
1233                 */
1234                i = j;                  // Will become the index of first space after search loop completion.
1235            }
1236            /*
1237             * At this point we did not found any user-specified label or localized name matching the substring.
1238             * Assume that the parsing should stop at the first space, on the basis that spaces are not allowed
1239             * in unit symbols. We make an exception if we detect that the part before the first space contains
1240             * digits (not allowed in unit symbols neither), in which case the substring may be something like
1241             * "100 feet".
1242             */
1243            if (hasDigit(symbols, start, i)) {
1244                i = end;                        // Restore the full length (until the first illegal character).
1245            }
1246        }
1247        if (!(operation.finished = (component != null))) {
1248            component = parseTerm(symbols, start, i, operation);            // May set 'operation.finished' flag.
1249        }
1250        if (operation.finished) {
1251            finish(position);           // For preventing interpretation of "degree minute" as "degree × minute".
1252        }
1253        unit = operation.apply(unit, component, start);
1254        position.setIndex(i);
1255        return unit;
1256    }
1257
1258    /**
1259     * Represents an operation to be applied between two terms parsed by
1260     * {@link UnitFormat#parseTerm(CharSequence, int, int, Operation)}.
1261     */
1262    private static final class Operation {
1263        /**
1264         * Meaning of some characters parsed by {@link UnitFormat#parse(CharSequence)}.
1265         * The {@code IMPLICIT} case is a multiplication without symbol, which can be
1266         * overridden by an explicit × or / symbol.
1267         */
1268        static final int NOOP = 0, IMPLICIT = 1, MULTIPLY = 2, DIVIDE = 3, EXPONENT = 4;
1269
1270        /**
1271         * The operation as one of the {@link #NOOP}, {@link #IMPLICIT}, {@link #MULTIPLY}
1272         * or {@link #DIVIDE} values.
1273         */
1274        int code;
1275
1276        /**
1277         * The symbols being parsed. Used only for formatting error message if needed.
1278         */
1279        private final CharSequence symbols;
1280
1281        /**
1282         * {@code true} if the parsed terms may be one or more words, possibly containing white spaces.
1283         * In such case, the parsing should not continue after those words.
1284         *
1285         * @see Position#finished
1286         */
1287        boolean finished;
1288
1289        /**
1290         * Creates an operation initialized to {@link #NOOP}.
1291         */
1292        Operation(final CharSequence symbols) {
1293            this.symbols = symbols;
1294        }
1295
1296        /**
1297         * Applies a multiplication or division operation between the given units.
1298         *
1299         * @param  unit      the left operand, which is the unit parsed so far.
1300         * @param  term      the right operation, which is the newly parsed unit.
1301         * @param  position  the parse position to report if parsing fail.
1302         */
1303        Unit<?> apply(final Unit<?> unit, final Unit<?> term, final int position) {
1304            switch (code) {
1305                case NOOP:     return term;
1306                case IMPLICIT:
1307                case MULTIPLY: return unit.multiply(term);
1308                case DIVIDE:   return unit.divide(term);
1309                case EXPONENT: {
1310                    if (UnitDimension.isDimensionless(term.getDimension())) {
1311                        final String symbol = term.getSymbol();
1312                        if (symbol == null || symbol.isEmpty()) {
1313                            final double scale = Units.toStandardUnit(term);
1314                            final int power = (int) scale;
1315                            if (power == scale) {
1316                                return unit.pow(power);
1317                            }
1318                        }
1319                    }
1320                    throw new ParserException(Errors.format(Errors.Keys.NotAnInteger_1, term), symbols, position);
1321                }
1322                default: throw new AssertionError(code);
1323            }
1324        }
1325
1326        /**
1327         * If this operation is a multiplication, replaces by division. Otherwise do nothing
1328         * (we do <strong>not</strong> replace division by multiplication). The intent is to
1329         * replace units like "m⋅s-1" by "m/s".
1330         *
1331         * @return whether the operation has been inverted.
1332         */
1333        boolean invert() {
1334            switch (code) {
1335                case IMPLICIT:
1336                case MULTIPLY: code = DIVIDE; return true;
1337                default: return false;
1338            }
1339        }
1340    }
1341
1342    /**
1343     * Parses a single unit symbol with its exponent.
1344     * The given symbol shall not contain multiplication or division operator except in exponent.
1345     * Parsing of fractional exponent as in "m2/3" is supported; other operations in the exponent
1346     * will cause an exception to be thrown.
1347     *
1348     * @param  symbols    the complete string specified by the user.
1349     * @param  lower      index where to begin parsing in the {@code symbols} string.
1350     * @param  upper      index after the last character to parse in the {@code symbols} string.
1351     * @param  operation  the operation to be applied (e.g. the term to be parsed is a multiplier or divisor of another unit).
1352     * @return the parsed unit symbol (never {@code null}).
1353     * @throws ParserException if a problem occurred while parsing the given symbols.
1354     */
1355    @SuppressWarnings("fallthrough")
1356    private Unit<?> parseTerm(final CharSequence symbols, final int lower, final int upper, final Operation operation)
1357            throws ParserException
1358    {
1359        final String uom = CharSequences.trimWhitespaces(symbols, lower, upper).toString();
1360        /*
1361         * Check for labels explicitly given by users. Those labels have precedence over the Seshat hard-coded
1362         * symbols. If no explicit label was found, check for symbols and names known to this UnitFormat instance.
1363         */
1364        Unit<?> unit = labelToUnit.get(uom);
1365        operation.finished = (unit != null);
1366        if (unit == null) {
1367            unit = Prefixes.getUnit(uom);
1368            if (unit == null) {
1369                final int length = uom.length();
1370                if (length == 0) {
1371                    return Units.UNITY;
1372                } else {
1373                    /*
1374                     * If the first character is a digit, presume that the term is a multiplication factor.
1375                     * The "*" character is used for raising the number on the left to the power on the right.
1376                     * Example: "10*6" is equal to one million. Seshat also handles the "^" character as "*".
1377                     *
1378                     * In principle, spaces are not allowed in unit symbols (in particular, UCUM specifies that
1379                     * spaces should not be interpreted as multication operators).  However in practice we have
1380                     * sometime units written in a form like "100 feet".
1381                     *
1382                     * If the last character is a super-script, then we assume a notation like "10⁻⁴".
1383                     */
1384                    final char c = uom.charAt(0);       // No need for code point because next condition is true only for BMP.
1385                    if (isDigit(c) || isSign(c)) {
1386                        final double multiplier;
1387                        try {
1388                            int s = uom.indexOf(' ');
1389                            if (s >= 0) {
1390                                final int next = CharSequences.skipLeadingWhitespaces(uom, s, length);
1391                                if (next < length && AbstractUnit.isSymbolChar(uom.codePointAt(next))) {
1392                                    operation.finished = true;  // For preventing attempt to continue parsing after "100 feet".
1393                                    multiplier = Double.parseDouble(uom.substring(0, s));
1394                                    return parseTerm(uom, s, length, new Operation(uom)).multiply(multiplier);
1395                                }
1396                            }
1397                            multiplier = parseMultiplicationFactor(uom);
1398                        } catch (NumberFormatException e) {
1399                            throw (ParserException) new ParserException(Errors.format(
1400                                    Errors.Keys.UnknownUnit_1, uom), symbols, lower).initCause(e);
1401                        }
1402                        if (operation.code == Operation.IMPLICIT) {
1403                            operation.code = Operation.EXPONENT;
1404                        }
1405                        return Units.UNITY.multiply(multiplier);
1406                    }
1407                }
1408                if (length >= 2) {
1409                    /*
1410                     * If the symbol ends with a digit (normal script or superscript), presume that this is the unit
1411                     * exponent.  That exponent can be a Unicode character (only one character in current UnitFormat
1412                     * implementation) or a number parseable with Integer.parseInt(String).
1413                     */
1414                    Fraction power = null;
1415                    int i = length;
1416                    int c = uom.codePointBefore(i);
1417                    i -= Character.charCount(c);
1418                    if (Characters.isSuperScript(c)) {
1419                        c = Characters.toNormalScript(c);
1420                        if (isDigit(c)) {
1421                            power = new Fraction(c - '0', 1);
1422                        }
1423                    } else if (isDigit(c)) {
1424                        while (i != 0) {
1425                            c = uom.codePointBefore(i);
1426                            final boolean isExponent = isDigit(c) || isDivisor(c);
1427                            if (isExponent || isSign(c)) {
1428                                i -= Character.charCount(c);
1429                            }
1430                            if (!isExponent) {
1431                                try {
1432                                    power = new Fraction(uom.substring(i));
1433                                } catch (NumberFormatException e) {
1434                                    // Should never happen unless the number is larger than 'int' capacity.
1435                                    throw (ParserException) new ParserException(Errors.format(
1436                                            Errors.Keys.UnknownUnit_1, uom), symbols, lower+i).initCause(e);
1437                                }
1438                                break;
1439                            }
1440                        }
1441                    }
1442                    if (power != null) {
1443                        /*
1444                         * At this point we have parsed the exponent. Before to parse the raw unit symbol,
1445                         * skip the exponent symbol (^, * or **) if any.
1446                         */
1447                        i = CharSequences.skipTrailingWhitespaces(uom, 0, i);
1448                        if (i != 0) {
1449                            // No need for code point because next conditions are true only in BMP.
1450                            switch (uom.charAt(i-1)) {
1451                                case Style.EXPONENT_OR_MULTIPLY: {
1452                                    if (i != 1 && uom.charAt(i-2) == Style.EXPONENT_OR_MULTIPLY) i--;
1453                                    // Fallthrough for skipping the next character and whitespaces.
1454                                }
1455                                case Style.EXPONENT: {
1456                                    i = CharSequences.skipTrailingWhitespaces(uom, 0, i - 1);
1457                                    break;
1458                                }
1459                            }
1460                        }
1461                        final String symbol = uom.substring(CharSequences.skipLeadingWhitespaces(uom, 0, i), i);
1462                        unit = labelToUnit.get(symbol);
1463                        operation.finished = (unit != null);
1464                        if (unit == null) {
1465                            unit = Prefixes.getUnit(symbol);
1466                        }
1467                        if (unit != null) {
1468                            int numerator   = power.numerator;
1469                            int denominator = power.denominator;
1470                            if (numerator < 0 && operation.invert()) {
1471                                numerator = -numerator;
1472                            }
1473                            if (numerator   != 1) unit = unit.pow (numerator);
1474                            if (denominator != 1) unit = unit.root(denominator);
1475                            return unit;
1476                        }
1477                    }
1478                }
1479                /*
1480                 * At this point, we have determined that the label is not a known unit symbol.
1481                 * It may be a unit name, in which case the label is not case-sensitive anymore.
1482                 */
1483                operation.finished = true;
1484                unit = fromName(uom);
1485                if (unit == null) {
1486                    if (CharSequences.regionMatches(symbols, lower, UNITY)) {
1487                        return Units.UNITY;
1488                    }
1489                    throw new ParserException(Errors.format(Errors.Keys.UnknownUnit_1, uom), symbols, lower);
1490                }
1491            }
1492        }
1493        return unit;
1494    }
1495
1496    /**
1497     * Parses a multiplication factor, which may be a single number or a base raised to an exponent.
1498     * For example all the following strings are equivalent: "1000", "1000.0", "1E3", "10*3", "10^3", "10³".
1499     */
1500    private static double parseMultiplicationFactor(final String term) throws NumberFormatException {
1501        final String exponent;
1502        int s = term.lastIndexOf(Style.EXPONENT_OR_MULTIPLY);        // Check standard UCUM symbol first.
1503        if (s >= 0 || (s = term.lastIndexOf(Style.EXPONENT)) >= 0) {
1504            exponent = term.substring(s + 1);
1505        } else {
1506            s = term.length();
1507            int c = term.codePointBefore(s);
1508            if (!Characters.isSuperScript(c)) {
1509                return Double.parseDouble(term);                     // No exponent symbol and no superscript found.
1510            }
1511            // Example: "10⁻⁴". Split in base and exponent.
1512            final StringBuilder buffer = new StringBuilder(s);
1513            do {
1514                buffer.appendCodePoint(Characters.toNormalScript(c));
1515                if ((s -= Character.charCount(c)) <= 0) break;
1516                c = term.codePointBefore(s);
1517            } while (Characters.isSuperScript(c));
1518            exponent = buffer.reverse().toString();
1519        }
1520        final int base = Integer.parseInt(term.substring(0, s));
1521        final int exp  = Integer.parseInt(exponent);
1522        return (base == 10) ? MathFunctions.pow10(exp) : Math.pow(base, exp);
1523    }
1524
1525    /**
1526     * Parses text from a string to produce a unit. The default implementation delegates to {@link #parse(CharSequence)}
1527     * and wraps the {@link ParserException} into a {@link ParseException} for compatibility with {@code java.text} API.
1528     *
1529     * @param  source  the text, part of which should be parsed.
1530     * @return a unit parsed from the string.
1531     * @throws ParseException if the given string can not be fully parsed.
1532     */
1533    @Override
1534    public Object parseObject(final String source) throws ParseException {
1535        try {
1536            return parse(source);
1537        } catch (ParserException e) {
1538            throw (ParseException) new ParseException(e.getLocalizedMessage(), e.getPosition()).initCause(e);
1539        }
1540    }
1541
1542    /**
1543     * Parses text from a string to produce a unit, or returns {@code null} if the parsing failed.
1544     * The default implementation delegates to {@link #parse(CharSequence, ParsePosition)} and catches
1545     * the {@link ParserException}.
1546     *
1547     * @param  source  the text, part of which should be parsed.
1548     * @param  pos     index and error index information as described above.
1549     * @return a unit parsed from the string, or {@code null} in case of error.
1550     */
1551    @Override
1552    public Object parseObject(final String source, final ParsePosition pos) {
1553        try {
1554            return parse(source, pos);
1555        } catch (ParserException e) {
1556            pos.setErrorIndex(e.getPosition());
1557            return null;
1558        }
1559    }
1560
1561    /**
1562     * Returns a clone of this unit format. The new unit format will be initialized to the same
1563     * {@linkplain #getLocale() locale} and {@linkplain #label(Unit, String) labels} than this format.
1564     *
1565     * @return a clone of this unit format.
1566     */
1567    @Override
1568    public UnitFormat clone() {
1569        final UnitFormat f = (UnitFormat) super.clone();
1570        f.unitToLabel = clone(f.unitToLabel);
1571        return f;
1572    }
1573
1574    /**
1575     * Clones the given map, which can be either a {@link HashMap}
1576     * or the instance returned by {@link Collections#emptyMap()}.
1577     */
1578    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
1579    private static <K,V> Map<K,V> clone(final Map<K,V> value) {
1580        if (value instanceof HashMap<?,?>) {
1581            return (Map<K,V>) ((HashMap<?,?>) value).clone();
1582        } else {
1583            return new HashMap<>();
1584        }
1585    }
1586}
